channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russia’s Top Officer Visited the East’s Front Line
item.description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi visited Ukraine and pledged U.S. support ‘until victory is won.’ An evacuation of civilians from Mariupol was underway.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers with the Ukrainian Territorial Defense Forces on Sunday in the Zaporizhzhia region in southeast Ukraine.

item.title: Inside China’s Zero-Covid Fortress, Xi Jinping Admits No Doubts
item.description: As the lockdown of Shanghai and outbreaks in Beijing and elsewhere batter the economy, China’s leader keeps a distance from the politically charged issue.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: A worker registering for a Covid test on Thursday in Beijing, where lockdowns so far have targeted individual buildings or streets, unlike in Shanghai.

item.title: Some Muslims Are Using Digital Rings to Count Recitations
item.description: Much like the fitness tools that count steps, these electronic devices help keep a record of the day’s religious recitations.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Afif Amireh for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man used an electronic prayer counter in Jerusalem’s Old City on Thursday. Shopkeepers said they started appearing five or seven years ago and were a hit.

item.title: Ahead of Philippines Election, Young People Rally Around Leni Robredo
item.description: As the election in the Philippines nears, tens of thousands of young people who fear another Marcos presidency are rallying around Leni Robredo, the country’s vice president.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally for Leni Robredo in early April in Pampanga, the Philippines. Ms. Robredo, the country’s vice president, is polling a distant second in the presidential race.

item.title: Pakistani Airstrikes Escalate Conflict on Afghan Border
item.description: The airstrikes killed at least 45 people, stoking fears of a violent resurgence of the conflict in eastern Afghanistan, which has become a base for Pakistani militants.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Safiullah Padshah and The New York Times

item.title: In Ukraine, A Body Bag and a Sister in Denial
item.description: The war in Ukraine is so big that it has shaken the world. But for a sister looking for her missing older brother, it was reduced to a visit to a morgue.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: Oksana Pokhodenko after identifying the remains of her older brother Oleksandr Pokhodenko at a morgue this month in Zmiiv, Ukraine.

item.title: She Promised to Empower Women. Will Honduras’s President Succeed?
item.description: The country’s first female leader, Xiomara Castro, is struggling to advance her feminist agenda 14 years after a coup ended the presidency of her husband, who pursued similar causes.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Joan Suazo
item.media:description: President Xiomara Castro during her inauguration ceremony in January in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.

item.title: Sinn Fein Poised to Make Historic Gains in Northern Ireland Elections
item.description: But Sinn Fein, which is leading in polls ahead of next week’s elections, hasn’t focused its campaign on unification with Ireland.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Walking past a Sinn Fein election poster next to a Republican mural on Falls Road, a Catholic stronghold in Belfast.

item.title: Ukrainian Official Outlines Intentional Ambiguity on Strikes Inside Russia
item.description: The strikes have been one of the most intriguing, and opaque, new elements of the recent fighting. But when it comes to confirming their origins, “we don’t say yes and we don’t say no,’’ said the official.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A fuel depot burining behind buildings in Belgorod, Russia, about 15 miles from the Ukrainian border, on April 1.

item.title: Mi’ilya, Christian Village in Israel, Digs Into Crusader Past
item.description: The residents of Mi’ilya long wondered what archaeological treasures lay beneath a crumbling castle. Now, some are excavating their homes to find out.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ruins in Mi’ilya, Israel, where many residents have caught the archaeology bug.

item.title: They Survived the Holocaust. Now, They Are Fleeing to Germany.
item.description: A complex operation is underway to evacuate Holocaust survivors from Ukraine. For rescuers and evacuees alike, it means confronting the past.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Galina Ploschenko, 88, in her room at a senior care center in Hanover, Germany.

item.title: On the Trail of Russian War Crimes
item.description: Lyudmyla Denisova, Ukraine’s top human rights official, is determined to right historical wrongs and make sure Russians are held to account.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lyudmyla Denisova, Ukraine’s human rights commissioner, has been working in overdrive since Russian troops invaded Ukraine in February.

item.title: Boris Becker Sentenced to Prison for Hiding Assets in Bankruptcy
item.description: The former tennis champion was found guilty by a London court on charges related to his 2017 insolvency.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Boris Becker and Lilian de Carvalho Monteiro, his partner, arriving at court in London on Friday. The sentence punctuated a startling fall from grace for the former tennis star.

item.title: In Echo of Soviet Era, Russia’s Movie Theaters Turn to Pirate Screenings
item.description: In a Cold War throwback, some venues are showing bootleg versions after Hollywood studios pulled films from the country. Still, viewer numbers have tanked.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: The Oktyabr movie theater in Moscow. Ticket sales to see films in Russia were reported to have fallen by about half in March, compared with the same period last year.

item.title: Russian Tycoon Criticized Putin’s War. Retribution Was Swift.
item.description: Oleg Tinkov spoke out against his country’s war in Ukraine. Now he is in hiding. In an exclusive interview he said, “I don’t believe in Russia’s future’’ under Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Oleg Tinkov in St. Petersburg in 2019.

item.title: U.S. Talk of ‘Victory’ Against Russia Has Some Allies Nervous
item.description: Europeans focused on helping Ukraine withstand the invasion worry that the United States may be “dragging everyone into a different war.”
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Jane Arraf and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dariia Piven, 33, visiting the grave of her parents in Irpin, Ukraine, on Sunday. They were shot in March by Russian soldiers, she said.

item.title: U.S. and Ukraine Officials: Top Russian Officer Went to War’s Frontline
item.description: The presence of such a high-ranking official on the front lines is highly unusual and comes amid what Western military analysts describe as increasing disarray within Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Gen. Valery Gerasimov, chief of the general staff of the Russian military, in Moscow, Russia, in December.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Pelosi Visits Ukraine
item.description: Plus Xi remains quiet on Covid lockdowns and young Filipinos rally for a long shot candidate.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: Régine, Whose Discotheque Gave Nightlife a New Dawn, Dies at 92
item.description: Credited with opening the first disco, she built an empire of glittering playgrounds for the Beautiful People in Paris, New York and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Régine in 1972. She built a $500 million empire of 23 clubs in Europe, the Middle East and the Americas, including Régine’s in Manhattan, the most famous nightspot of its era.

item.title: ISIS Launches Bloody New Chapter in Afghanistan
item.description: At least 100 people have died in terrorist attacks over the past two weeks, as the Islamic State targets minorities in Afghanistan and aims to undermine the Taliban government.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boys’ school in Kabul that was bombed last month.

item.title: The ‘Ghost of Kyiv’ Is a Myth, Ukraine Acknowledges
item.description: The legend of a pilot who shot down numerous Russian aircraft was one of the more successful pieces of propaganda in Ukraine’s information war.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pieces of a downed aircraft in a Kyiv neighborhood in February.

item.title: In Egypt’s Big Ramadan TV Drama ‘The Choice’, the President Is the Hero
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi says “The Choice” tells the truth about his rise. Critics say it’s a rewriting of recent history from an industry increasingly cowed under his rule.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A billboard in Cairo promotes “The Choice 3,” a Ramadan television series about President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s rise to power.

item.title: 100 Civilians Evacuated From Mariupol Steel Factory, Officials Say
item.description: The Ukrainian president said that civilians were being evacuated from the Azovstal steel factory and are headed to a “controlled area.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:description: Evacuees, including civilians who left the area near the steel plant in Mariupol, arrive in the Donetsk Region of Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: Nancy Pelosi and Democratic Lawmakers Say U.S. Will Support Ukraine
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi with a congressional delegation at a news conference on Sunday in Rzeszow, Poland.

item.title: A Grim Existence
item.description: Many Ukrainians are in mobilization mode.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Valentina Mutyeva, 72, sits by candlelight and flashlight in a basement shelter where she has been living under a residential building for a month under constant shelling in the village of Avdiivka in Eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Beijing Covid Outbreak: New Restrictions Imposed, but No Full Lockdown
item.description: Officials in China’s capital are striving to contain a coronavirus outbreak while avoiding public anger of the kind that has erupted in Shanghai.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Workers in protective suits on Sunday in one of Beijing’s most affluent districts, Chaoyang, where many of the recent coronavirus cases have been detected.

item.title: Deaths of Foreign Fighters Renew Attention on Ukraine War Volunteers
item.description: At least three foreigners have been killed fighting with Ukraine’s International Legion. One analyst said many would-be volunteers underestimated the danger from Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Malcolm Nance, a U.S. Navy veteran serving in Ukraine’s International Legion, contrasted the war in Ukraine with the American invasion of Iraq. “You’re the hunted now,” he said.

item.title: Bodies of Three Men Found in Bucha, Ukrainian Officials Say
item.description: A police chief said that victims’ bodies were discovered in a forest, and showed signs of mutilation.
item.dc:creator: Esha Ray
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bodies of civilians have been found in Bucha, Ukraine, ever since Russian troops pulled out in late March.

item.title: 4 Canadian Military Cadets Die After Car Plunges Into River
item.description: The men were set to graduate from the Royal Military College in a few weeks, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina

item.title: Kremlin Deploys New Troops to Ukraine as Both Sides Gird for a War of Attrition
item.description: Moscow is hitting fuel refineries and imperiling critical harvests, while Ukrainian forces are being buoyed by an influx of heavy weapons.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Jane Arraf and Michael Levenson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Motorists lining up for fuel in Lviv, Ukraine, on Saturday amid shortages brought about by Russian attacks on a major refinery.

item.title: As Ambassadors Left Town, the Pope’s Emissary Remained in Kyiv
item.description: Through shelling, street fights in the suburbs and the flight of thousands through Ukraine’s capital, the Vatican’s diplomatic mission stayed put.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Pope Francis greeting refugees from Ukraine during his weekly general audience at the Vatican this month.

item.title: Women and Children Evacuated Out of Mariupol’s Azovstal Steel Plant
item.description: A Ukrainian commander and Russian news agencies said about 20 civilians were able to leave the steel factory in the besieged city of Mariupol. An unknown number of civilians remains at the plant.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: About 20 women and children were reportedly evacuated from the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol on Saturday. Russian forces have repeatedly shelled the complex, in an attempt to take full control over the entirety of the city after weeks of laying siege to it.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russia Looted Ancient Gold Artifacts From a Museum
item.description: According to Ukrainian officials, Russian soldiers, aided by a mysterious expert, broke into a museum and spirited away priceless artifacts from the Scythian empire.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: What is thought to be a Scythian gold helmet, displayed at a museum exhibition in Kyiv last year.

item.title: Review: ‘Dead in the Water,’ by Matthew Campbell & Kit Chellel
item.description: In Matthew Campbell and Kit Chellel’s real-life whodunit “Dead in the Water,” Big Oil, Big Insurance and global corruption clash on a giant scale.
item.dc:creator: Mark Bowden
item.category: Dead in the Water: A True Story of Hijacking, Murder, and a Global Maritime Conspiracy (Book)

item.title: Ukraine Grapples With Fuel Shortages After Russian Attacks
item.description: Officials in Kyiv have urged residents to use public transportation rather than private vehicles in an effort to save fuel for the military.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Drivers crowded a gas station in Lviv on Saturday, amid a country-wide fuel shortage caused by Russian attacks.

item.title: What to Stream in May
item.description: Next month’s streaming options include new Sally Rooney fare, “Masterpiece” and a new season of “Hacks.”
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Sunflower Oil ‘Vanishes’ as Ukraine War Grinds On
item.description: Several British supermarkets have joined other chains around the world in asking shoppers to limit their cooking oil purchases, as supplies dwindle and prices rise.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Steve Parsons/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Global cooking oil shortages, exacerbated by the war in Ukraine, have led to purchase restrictions in Ashford, England.

item.title: Flagship Hudson’s Bay Store Turned Over to Indigenous Group
item.description: The Hudson’s Bay Company has turned over its former flagship store to an Indigenous group with big ambitions for the space.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

item.title: Trade Barriers From the Ukraine War Are Sending Food Prices Higher
item.description: Dozens of countries have thrown up trade barriers in the past two months to protect scarce supplies of food and commodities, but experts say the policies will only exacerbate a global food crisis.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bread factory in Al Hasakah, Syria, in February. Price increases are felt particularly keenly in poorer countries in the Middle East and sub-Saharan Africa, which depend on imported food.

item.title: Civilians Keep Arriving at Besieged Steel Complex in Mariupol, Fighters Say
item.description: That citizens are still seeking to shelter at the plant, where there is no prospect of escape or rescue, offers a testament to what they must be facing elsewhere in the devastated city.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Aleksandra Koroleva
item.media:description: The Azovstal steel complex on Friday, after weeks of Russian shelling. It has become a refuge of last resort for civilians in the Ukrainian port city of Mariupol.

item.title: Death of Former Marine Fighting in Ukraine Confirmed by Family
item.description: Willy Joseph Cancel Jr., 22, died in combat earlier this week, according to his uncle. He is believed to be the first American killed while fighting in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Dave Philipps
item.media:description: Willy Joseph Cancel Jr. in Ukraine in an undated photograph provided by his family.

item.title: Biden Seeks to Lure Russia’s Top Scientists to the U.S.
item.description: Legislation proposed by the president would suspend the requirement that Russian scientists have a sponsoring employer to gain a visa.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House on Thursday, where he called on Congress to authorize $33 billion in aid to Ukraine.

item.title: Coronavirus Cases Are Rising Across the U.S., but Most Are Mild
item.description: Hospitalizations remain low, partly a reflection of greater immunity in the population.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Cahalan and Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: The subway system in the San Francisco Bay Area reinstated a mask mandate on Thursday.

item.title: Fighters Share Desperate Videos From Mariupol Steel Plant to Promote Story
item.description: With independent media unable to access this last military holdout, videos from inside function as pleas for help and publicity on social media.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Sarah Kerr and Ainara Tiefenthäler

item.title: Why Americans Became More Vulnerable to Oil Price Spikes
item.description: When prices soared years ago, Americans launched broad efforts to wean the nation off oil and gas to protect households from price swings. But then supply rose and plans fizzled.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi and Maggie Astor

item.title: Started Out as a Fish. How Did It End Up Like This?
item.description: A meme about the transitional fossil Tiktaalik argues that although we did come out of the sea, we aren’t doing just fine.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:description: Tiktaalik roseae, the extinct limbed fish that flopped its way onto land one day 375 million years ago. We’ve been flopping ever since.

item.title: Leader of E.U. Border Agency Departs After Accusations of Abuses During His Tenure
item.description: The head of the agency, which became emblematic of the bloc’s hardening migration policy, has faced mounting allegations of mismanagement, harassment and human rights abuses at Europe’s borders.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Fabrice Leggeri, the head of the European Border Agency, last year in Warsaw, Poland.

item.title: Amid Hardening Western Resolve, Signs of Russia’s Stalling in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Pentagon officials say the Russian drive in Donbas is being hampered by poor logistics and stiff Ukrainian resistance.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainan soldiers walk on a street, near destroyed vehicles from Russian forces in the village of Shestovytsia in northern Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: During Ramadan, Palestinians Barred From Aqsa Turn to Smugglers
item.description: For Palestinian Muslims, praying at the Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem is an important part of Ramadan. Those barred by Israel are finding ways to get there anyway.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel’s separation barrier in the West Bank city of Bethlehem. Some Palestinians are finding ways around or over it.

item.title: Beijing Closes Schools as It Tries to Contain an Outbreak
item.description: The city is heading into a long holiday weekend, and officials are discouraging travel and unnecessary gatherings.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Lining up for coronavirus testing in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: In Ukraine War, a Long Journey Begins in Prosecuting Rape
item.description: U.N. officials and human rights investigators are rushing more resources to authorities in Ukraine to help prosecute sex crimes.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Battle-damaged buildings in Kharkiv. In the first two weeks of April, about 400 cases of sexual violence by Russian soldiers were reported to Ukraine’s ombudswoman for human rights.

item.title: Anglo-Saxon Kings Made Sure to Eat Their Vegetables, Study Shows
item.description: Contrary to popular belief, the ruling classes gorged on meat only on rare occasions, according to an analysis of more than 2,000 skeletons buried during medieval times.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer

item.title: Vaccines for Young Children
item.description: The federal government is telling us two different stories.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A Moderna Covid-19 vaccine trial in Commack, N.Y., last year.

item.title: Solar Industry ‘Frozen’ as Biden Administration Investigates China
item.description: More than 300 solar projects in the United States have been canceled or delayed in recent weeks because of an investigation by the Commerce Department.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:description: A solar panel production line in Baoding, China. Tariffs on Chinese solar panels have been in place since 2012.

item.title: Millions of South Koreans Could Soon Get Younger (on Paper)
item.description: South Korea has three ways of calculating age, often adding a year or two to the international standard. The incoming president wants to change that.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Under one Korean method of calculating age, babies are considered to be a year old at birth.

item.title: Ukraine Identifies Russian Soldiers in Bucha Atrocities
item.description: In the first detailed set of allegations since the invasion, Ukrainian officials published the names and photos of Russian soldiers they say tortured civilians in a suburb of Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A disabled tank in Bucha, a suburb of Kyiv, this month.

item.title: Ireland’s Census Collects Time Capsules to Be Opened in 100 Years
item.description: The makers of the survey included a space for people to write or draw a message. The contents of these so-called time capsules will be revealed in 100 years.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:description: The coast in Dublin last year.

item.title: Weighing Risk When the Reporting Is Dangerous
item.description: A security team watches out for Times journalists abroad. There are strategies in place, but sometimes there’s no other choice but to leave a country.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers detained an antiwar protester in Moscow on Feb. 25. The Russian government outlawed independent information about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in early March.
